definitions: stable natural language developed from mixing of parent languages
person of mixed European and African or Caribbean descent, especially in former colonies
style of cooking originating in Louisiana combining French, African, Spanish, and Caribbean influences
examples: Haitian Creole evolved from French and African languages
Many people in Louisiana speak a French-based creole
The Creole community preserved their unique cultural traditions
Her grandmother was a proud New Orleans Creole
The restaurant specializes in authentic Creole cuisine
Shrimp creole remains a classic Louisiana dish

definitions: very thin pancake of French origin made from flour, eggs, and milk
light fabric with wrinkled surface texture used for clothing and decorations
soft rubber material used for shoe soles with characteristic ridged pattern
examples: She ordered strawberry crepes for breakfast
The French restaurant serves both sweet and savory crepes
Her wedding dress was made from ivory silk crepe
The black crepe fabric draped beautifully
His shoes had crepe soles for better traction
The crepe rubber wore down after years of use

definitions: gradual increase in loudness or intensity of musical sound leading to a peak
progressive increase in intensity, force, or effect of any phenomenon or activity
examples: The symphony built to a powerful crescendo in the final movement
The conductor signaled for a dramatic crescendo
Public protests reached a crescendo before the election
The argument built to an emotional crescendo

definitions: curved shape resembling a segment of a ring tapering to points at ends
any object having the distinctive curved shape of a crescent moon
crescent-shaped geographic region, especially the Fertile Crescent of ancient Mesopotamia
examples: The crescent moon hung low in the evening sky
The Islamic symbol features a star and crescent
She wore a silver crescent pendant around her neck
The pastries were shaped like tiny crescents
The Fertile Crescent was the birthplace of agriculture
They lived on Crescent Street near the park

definitions: highest point or top of something, especially a hill, mountain or ridge
tuft or growth of feathers, fur or skin on the head of a bird or animal
distinctive device or bearing depicted on a coat of arms above the shield
foamy top of a wave, especially when breaking
examples: They reached the crest of the hill at sunset
The trail follows the mountain crest for miles
The cardinal's red crest stood up when alarmed
The cockatoo raised its yellow crest
The family crest displayed three golden lions
Each knight bore his crest on his shield
Surfers waited for waves to crest before riding
White foam appeared as the wave crested

definitions: deep open crack or fissure in a glacier or ice sheet
any deep crack or fissure in rock or earth
examples: The climber fell into a hidden crevasse on the glacier
Crevasses can be hundreds of feet deep
The earthquake opened dangerous crevasses in the ground
They carefully navigated around the crevasse

definitions: narrow opening or crack in a hard surface, especially in rock or wall
examples: Plants grew from tiny crevices in the rock face
The mouse disappeared into a crevice in the wall
Water seeped through crevices in the foundation
She found coins hidden in crevices of the old sofa

definitions: group of people working together, especially on a ship, aircraft, or film
informal group of friends or associates who spend time together
examples: The ship's crew prepared for the storm
The film crew worked eighteen-hour days
He always hung out with the same crew
My crew and I are going to the concert

definitions: member of a crew, especially on a ship or aircraft
examples: The crewman secured the cargo before departure
Three crewmen were injured in the accident
Each crewman had specific duties during emergencies
The experienced crewman taught the new recruits

definitions: small bed with high barred sides for a baby or very young child
translation or notes used dishonestly in an examination or plagiarized work
structure for storing grain or animal feed, typically with slatted walls
small, crude dwelling or shelter
examples: The baby slept peacefully in her crib
They assembled the new crib for the nursery
The teacher caught him using a crib during the exam
His essay was obviously a crib from Wikipedia
The farmer filled the corn crib after harvest
Mice had gotten into the grain crib
The miner's crib was barely large enough for a bed
They lived in a tiny crib near the tracks

definitions: painful stiffness in the neck or back from muscle strain or spasm
examples: She woke up with a terrible crick in her neck
Sleeping wrong gave him a crick in his back
The massage therapist worked out the crick in his shoulder
A hot compress helped ease the crick

definitions: jumping insect that produces chirping sounds by rubbing its wings together
team sport played with bat and ball on a large grass field with wickets
examples: Crickets chirped loudly in the summer evening
The cricket jumped away when disturbed
England won the cricket match by six wickets
He played cricket for his university team

definitions: person who plays cricket, especially at a professional or skilled level
examples: The famous cricketer signed autographs after the match
She became a professional cricketer at age eighteen
Several cricketers were selected for the national team
The retired cricketer now works as a coach

definitions: official who makes public announcements in the streets or marketplace, historically a town crier
person who cries or weeps frequently or easily
examples: The town crier announced the royal proclamation
Medieval criers rang bells to gather crowds
She was known as a crier at sad movies
The baby was a constant crier

definitions: action or omission that constitutes an offense punishable by law
action or activity considered to be evil, shameful, or wrong
examples: Murder is considered the most serious crime
The police are investigating a series of crimes
It's a crime to waste such talent
Charging those prices should be a crime

definitions: person who has committed a crime or been legally convicted of a crime
relating to crime or the treatment and punishment of criminals
examples: The criminal was sentenced to ten years in prison
Police arrested three suspected criminals
She specialized in criminal law
The criminal justice system needs reform

definitions: state of being criminal or tendency to commit crimes as a behavioral pattern
examples: Studies examined the causes of youth criminality
Poverty alone doesn't explain criminality
The neighborhood struggled with increasing criminality
His descent into criminality began in his teens

definitions: action of turning something into a criminal offense by making it illegal under law
examples: The criminalization of marijuana remains controversial
Activists opposed the criminalization of homelessness
The new law led to criminalization of previously legal activities
Criminalization of certain behaviors increased prison populations

definitions: expert who studies crime, criminals, and the criminal justice system scientifically
examples: The criminologist testified about crime patterns in court
Leading criminologists studied the effectiveness of rehabilitation
She became a criminologist after years as a detective
The criminologist published research on juvenile offenders

definitions: scientific study of crime, criminals, criminal behavior, and the criminal justice system
examples: She earned her doctorate in criminology
Criminology combines sociology, psychology, and law
The criminology department researched recidivism rates
Modern criminology uses advanced statistical methods

definitions: fold, wrinkle, or wave pressed or pinched into something, especially hair or fabric
something that restricts or inhibits development or progress
examples: She added crimps to her hair with a curling iron
The fabric had decorative crimps along the edge
Rising costs put a crimp in their expansion plans
Bad weather put a crimp in the construction schedule

definitions: rich deep red color inclining to purple
examples: The sunset painted the sky in shades of crimson
She wore a beautiful crimson dress to the gala
Harvard's colors are crimson and white
Blood stained the bandage crimson

definitions: sudden movement or feeling of embarrassment, disgust, or discomfort causing one to shrink back
examples: His terrible joke made everyone cringe
She felt a cringe of embarrassment watching the video
The memory still makes me cringe years later
The cringe was visible on their faces

definitions: offensive term for a person who is unable to walk or move normally due to disability
something that severely damages or impairs functioning
examples: The word cripple is now considered offensive
Historical texts often used cripple insensitively
The cyber attack was a cripple to their operations
The scandal became a political cripple

definitions: thin slice of potato fried until crunchy and brittle, called a chip in American English
examples: She bought a packet of cheese and onion crisps
The crisps were perfectly salted and crunchy
British crisps are American potato chips
The vending machine sold various flavored crisps

definitions: principle or standard by which something may be judged, evaluated, or decided
examples: Academic excellence was the main criterion for admission
Each criterion must be met for approval
The selection criteria included experience and education
Cost was not the only criterion for their decision

definitions: person who expresses reasoned judgment of artistic works, especially professionally
person who expresses disapproval and points out faults or problems
examples: The film critic gave it four stars
Art critics praised her innovative technique
He was his own harshest critic
Critics of the policy demanded changes

definitions: quality of being extremely important or at a point of crisis requiring immediate action
state in nuclear physics where a chain reaction becomes self-sustaining
examples: The criticality of the situation demanded immediate response
They assessed the criticality of each system failure
The reactor approached criticality during startup
Nuclear criticality requires precise control

definitions: expression of disapproval based on perceived faults or mistakes
detailed analysis and assessment of a literary or artistic work
examples: The proposal faced harsh criticism from experts
She couldn't handle criticism well
His literary criticism appeared in major journals
The book offers thoughtful criticism of modern poetry

definitions: detailed analysis and assessment of something, especially a literary, philosophical, or artistic work
examples: Her critique of the novel was published in the journal
The professor provided a thorough critique of the thesis
Students wrote critiques of famous paintings
The critique highlighted both strengths and weaknesses

definitions: handicraft in which yarn is made into fabric using a hooked needle to form loops
examples: Her grandmother taught her to crochet blankets
The delicate crochet work adorned the tablecloth
She sells handmade crochet items at craft fairs
Crochet patterns filled the instruction book

definitions: plates, dishes, cups, and other similar items made of earthenware or china collectively
examples: The antique crockery was displayed in the cabinet
They bought new crockery for the restaurant
Fine crockery graced the dinner table
The moving company carefully packed the crockery

definitions: large predatory semiaquatic reptile with long jaws, powerful tail, and armored skin
examples: The crocodile lurked just beneath the water's surface
Nile crocodiles can grow over twenty feet long
Saltwater crocodiles are the largest living reptiles
The zoo's crocodile feeding drew large crowds

definitions: ugly old woman, often portrayed as a witch or having magical powers in folklore
examples: The fairy tale featured an evil crone with magical powers
The old crone lived alone at the forest's edge
Medieval stories often depicted crones as wise women
The crone stirred her mysterious potion

definitions: practice of appointing friends and associates to positions regardless of qualifications
examples: The administration was accused of blatant cronyism
Cronyism undermined the merit-based hiring system
Corporate cronyism led to unqualified board members
The scandal exposed years of political cronyism

definitions: person who engages in fraudulent or criminal practices
bend or curve in something that is otherwise straight
hooked staff used by shepherds to catch sheep
examples: The crook stole thousands from elderly victims
Police arrested the crooks after a lengthy investigation
There was a slight crook in the tree branch
The river made a sharp crook to the east
The shepherd used his crook to guide the flock
The bishop carried a ceremonial crook

definitions: singer, typically male, who sings sentimental songs in a soft, intimate style
examples: Frank Sinatra was a famous crooner of his era
The crooner's smooth voice filled the nightclub
Jazz crooners dominated the music scene in the 1940s
The elderly crooner still performed at local venues

definitions: singing in a soft, sentimental, or intimate manner
examples: His crooning style appealed to romantic audiences
She heard soft crooning from the nursery
The crooning of lullabies helped the baby sleep
Jazz crooning became popular in the 1930s

definitions: cultivated plant grown as food, especially grain, fruit, or vegetables
total amount harvested of a particular cultivated plant in a season
very short haircut or hairstyle
short whip used in horse riding
examples: Corn was their most profitable crop this year
The drought destroyed many crops
This year's wheat crop exceeded expectations
Farmers celebrated a bumper crop
She got a stylish crop for summer
His military crop suited his angular face
The jockey raised his crop to urge the horse forward
She carried a leather riding crop

definitions: person who grows crops, especially as a sharecropper or tenant farmer
heavy fall or failure, used in the phrase 'come a cropper'
examples: The sharecropper worked the land for decades
Cotton croppers faced difficult economic conditions
He came a cropper on the icy sidewalk
The business venture came a cropper

definitions: game played on grass where players hit wooden balls through hoops using mallets
examples: They played croquet on the mansion's lawn
The croquet set included six mallets and wickets
Victorian ladies enjoyed afternoon croquet parties
Championship croquet requires precision and strategy

definitions: horizontal bar connecting two vertical posts, especially in sports goals or structures
examples: The shot hit the crossbar and bounced away
The goalkeeper touched the crossbar to check his position
The gate's crossbar prevented vehicles from entering
Gymnasts performed routines on the horizontal crossbar

definitions: medieval weapon consisting of a bow fixed crosswise on a stock that shoots bolts
examples: Medieval soldiers armed themselves with crossbows
The crossbow bolt pierced the armor
Modern crossbows are used for hunting
He practiced archery with both bow and crossbow

definitions: process of producing offspring by mating two different varieties, breeds, or species
examples: Crossbreeding created hardier crop varieties
The farmer practiced selective crossbreeding
Dog crossbreeding produced many designer breeds
Crossbreeding improved disease resistance in plants

definitions: gunfire from two or more directions passing through the same area
situation of being caught between opposing views, forces, or criticisms
examples: Civilians were caught in the crossfire between rival gangs
The troops avoided enemy crossfire positions
She found herself in the crossfire of office politics
The mayor was caught in the crossfire of public criticism

definitions: place where roads, railroad tracks, or paths intersect or where one may cross
action of going across or traversing from one side to another
journey across water, especially by ship
examples: Use the pedestrian crossing to cross safely
The railroad crossing had warning lights
The border crossing took three hours
Her crossing of the desert was perilous
The Atlantic crossing lasted seven days
Rough seas made for a difficult crossing

definitions: work that appeals to different audiences or combines different styles or genres
place where one thing crosses over to another, such as a bridge or passage
vehicle combining features of a car and SUV
examples: The album was a successful jazz-pop crossover
The movie was a crossover between horror and comedy
Use the crossover to reach the other platform
The highway crossover connected the divided lanes
They bought a crossover instead of a minivan
Crossover vehicles offer better fuel economy than SUVs

definitions: place where two or more roads meet and cross each other
critical point where an important decision must be made
examples: The accident happened at the busy crossroad
Turn left at the next crossroad
She stood at a crossroad in her career
The nation faced a historic crossroad

definitions: unwanted transfer of signals between communication channels causing interference
rapid conversational exchange, especially of witty remarks
examples: Electronic crosstalk disrupted the phone conversation
Engineers worked to eliminate crosstalk between circuits
The comedians engaged in hilarious crosstalk
Their witty crosstalk entertained the audience

definitions: wind blowing across one's direction of travel, especially affecting aircraft or vehicles
examples: Strong crosswinds made the landing difficult
The pilot compensated for the crosswind
Crosswinds pushed the car toward the shoulder
Cyclists struggled against the fierce crosswind
